bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, October 9, 1930

div1.p: Carter thanks Frost for sending her a copy of the bibliography so quickly, and compliments him on the Table of Contents of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, October 9, 1930
div1.opener:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
October 9, 1930.
Dr. Wade H. Frost,
School of Hygiene and Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
Thank you very much (a) for the remainder of the Bibliography,
as typed by Miss Frederick and (b) the card file, from which it was
typed. Both reached me this morning. I agree that it was safer for you
to hold your copy of the Bibliography as a “control” until we got yours
our carboncopy. I had hoped that might be two carbon copies of the
Bibliography, but since this is not the case, Miss Brown and I will go
ahead with the one you sent us and only accept your offer to send over
the original if the corrections prove so extensive as to make it advis-
able for the two copies to be identical. This prior to the final typ-
ing for Colonel Russell.

I have, of course, only glanced over the additional pages of
the Bibliography, which looks extremely well in its typed form. For this,
my felicitations to Miss Frederick! I note with regret, though not with
surprise, considering how much of the last part of the work you had to
do under pressure, that Gorgas' name does not appear in the Bibliogra-
phy. As you may remember, our tentative plan was to put it in re
“critical number” of aegypti, as adapted from Ross' (1911) “critical
number” for Anopheles (Sec. 1. p. 30, original MS). This, if you could
find no better reference.

In reading over the MS.. which I have done with intense inter-
est and satisfaction, but under extremely unfavorable physical condi-
tions, I have, of course, “picked up” some of the “minor residual errors,”
which, as you wrote, can be corrected in the galley proof. The only one
that seems (possibly) worth noting just now is the f. n. on page 117
(sent me as a replacement a few days ago.). This foot note now reads:

“(1) Béranger-Féraud (1890, p. 27) is of the opinion that there was yellow
aboard ships in the Bight of Benin as early as 1520”...

“(1) Béranger-Féraud (1890, p. 27) is of the opinion that there may have
been yellow fever aboard ships”.....
B-Féraud never mentioned the above as being his definite conviction.

The above, of course, can also wait for the galley proof, however as it
seems to come within your category of “corrections...probably not trans-
cribed on the copy sent Colonel Russell”...I send it for what it is worth.

I much appreciate your thoughtfulness in telling me that there
is no need to rush myself in checking the over the Bibliography. It is
a relief to know this, as I am still feeling very badly and find it hard
hard
-2-
to push things beyond a certain point. I am, none the less, extremely
glad and most grateful to you and to Miss Frederick, for the getting the
material over here in time for Miss Brown and myself to put in this week-
end on it. This, because as I wrote you, the coming Sunday is one of the
only two free ones she has a month. Surely, she too has entered into the
spirit of the work on the book!
I must break this off or miss the last collection of mail.

closer.salute: Hastily, but none the less, gratefully,
closer.seg:
P. S. Your table of Contents is “a gem and a jewel! Since reading it,
I am no longer concerned at the probable necessity of turning the indexing
over to some good routine man, specializing in such work. By the way, I
haven't read it all, as my carbon ends with Page ix, Chapter xiii, being
the last one on that page, and the first chapter of the Section on Africa.
L. A. C.
